title: U.K. Mortgages Remain Robust Despite Brexit Turmoil
text:
Low mortgage rates continue to buoy U.K. home sales despite mounting political and economic uncertainty, according to monthly data from industry body UK Finance on Wednesday.



Net mortgage approvals for home purchases totaled 43,957 in August, a decline from July, but a 3.2% increase from the same month last year, according to figures from UK Finance, which pools data from main street lenders.

Mortgage lending has hovered around consistent levels for several months now, even as uncertainty surrounding Britain’s much-delayed exit from the European Union has clearly affected other measures of market health, including sales and new listings.



“Buyer demand for mortgage products has been the one area of the market to remain buoyant in the face of political uncertainty,” said Marc von Grundherr, director of London estate agency Benham & Reeves, in a statement following the data release.



The fraught politics over Brexit, which is slated to proceed on Oct. 31, have slowed sales across the country as sellers and buyers broadly take a wait-and-see approach.

The average quoted interest rate for a long-term variable five-year-fixed mortgage, a standard home loan type in the U.K., was only 1.92% in August, a decline from over 2% at the start of the year, according to analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics.



Pantheon’s chief U.K. economist, Samuel Tombs, wrote in a note on Wednesday that he expects such home loans to become even more affordable by the end of the year. “Accordingly, we continue to expect housing demand to hold up well despite levels of political uncertainty,”he said.
